awd_titl_txt: Efficient Temporal-Spatial Spectrum Sharing through Voluntary Exchange
awd_abstract_narration:
The goal of this project is to develop more efficient and flexible access to radio spectrum. Typically radio spectrum bands are allocated by the FCC to commercial and noncommercial users who can be thought of as "primary users." Such a user may not need to utilize the spectrum all of the time. This has led to the existence of "secondary users" who access the spectrum opportunistically. However, such secondary usage can bring interference to other secondary users and primary users. Furthermore, primary users have little motivation to permit this type of secondary use as there is no benefit to them and only risk.
 
To encourage spectrum sharing and enhance spectrum efficiency, it is important to have a mechanism or solution concept that creates the correct incentives for both primary and secondary users. However, there are significant communication costs as well as limitations involved in the sale or exchange of spectrum bands. Therefore, spectrum sharing through voluntary exchange is proposed to address these challenges for efficient spectrum access. The research project outlined here will determine which type of spectrum sharing mechanisms would be better for primary users, secondary users, and for society.

More specifically, voluntary exchange mechanisms including monetary exchange and barter are examined to promote spectrum sharing between primary and secondary users where both the communication costs and constraints for information exchange are reflected in the spectrum sharing models. Moreover, new ways to avoid interference for users located in different regions are examined to further enhance spectrum efficiency.

Sharing spectrum and improving spectrum efficiency are current priorities of lawmakers and spectrum regulators, as evidenced through the National Broadband Plan (2010), the PCAST report on sharing spectrum between the federal government and non-government users (2012), the Spectrum Act of 2012, and two presidential memoranda on the topic (2010 and 2013). Clearly, development and application of appropriate economic theories to foster more opportunities for spectrum sharing is a desirable outcome with significant broader impact to all stakeholders, including commercial broadband providers, public safety, homeland security, and national defense.

por.por_cntn:
The concept of cognitive radio was introduced over a decade ago as a solution for spectrum scarcity by enabling opportunistic access from secondary users. However, there is no motivation for primary users to permit secondary use of their licensed spectrum, as there is no benefit to primary users and in fact only risk. To encourage spectrum sharing and enhance spectrum efficiency, this project focuses on incentive-driven mechanisms for both primary and secondary users. One approach to motivate primary users is to have them voluntarily sell their spectrum to or make exchanges with secondary users. However, there are significant communication costs as well as limitations involved in the sale of spectrum or the exchange. Moreover, such an approach should not restrict concurrent use of spectrum by spatially separated users. Therefore, temporal-spatial spectrum sharing through voluntary exchange has been studied to address these challenges for efficient spectrum access. 

While one of the major challenges in spectrum sharing is to mutually motivate spectrum users and optimize overall efficiency, communication costs for information exchange and constraints in obtaining complete information usually discourage individual users from sharing the spectrum in the most efficient manner. Our research greatly alleviates or resolves these issues and can help to determine which type of spectrum sharing mechanisms would be better for primary users, secondary users, and the society. Specifically, voluntary exchange mechanisms including monetary exchange and barter have been examined to promote spectrum sharing between primary and secondary users. Both the communication costs and constraints for information exchange are reflected in the spectrum sharing models. Social welfare is also used to determine the overall efficiency of these mechanisms and how these mechanisms are influenced by communication costs and constraints. Moreover, with novel interference avoidance schemes embedded in these mechanisms, spatially separated users are allowed to utilize the same frequency channel at the same time, which further enhances spectrum efficiency. 

Graduate and undergraduate students, including those from under-represented groups, have been funded as part of the project. The students have gained significant amount of knowledge in the general area of wireless communications, and in the specific domain of spectrum sharing and economic games. Findings of the project have been published in or submitted to prestigious journals and conference proceedings. They have also been incorporated in the instruction and curriculum of graduate and undergraduate courses. The findings in the project can be applied to problems of allocating other resources such as a commonly owned water source or agricultural area.
